Award.AwardTitle: CC-NIE Network Infrastructure: KGAP: Bridging th Gap in Network Flexibility and Performance for Genomics and Data-Intensive Research at Kansas State University

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project utilizes NSF support to enhance the networking capabilities at Kansas State University to support high-end applications in science and engineering, particularly bioinformatics, with applications in OpenFlow research and privacy/security.

The project adds a pair of high-performance, low-latency OpenFlow-compatible enterprise routers to provide a foundation for upgrading KSU's campus core network to 40GbE, and 10GbE to most major research buildings on campus. KSU is adding another router to set up a science DMZ for research in OpenFlow and Smart Grid research. This impacts over 24 departments in 16 locations, 8,000 undergrad majors, 2,000 grad students, 700 faculty, and $88M in funded research. This system, along with the expertise provided by related personnel, serves as a common hybrid network technology platform for a number of research groups in genomics, smart grids, GIS/environmental modeling and computer security at K-State and off-campus partners.

The project increases KSU's ability to look deeper in modeling genomes, Smart Grids, GIS economies and computer security through bringing much greater bandwidth and flexibility to bear, attacking grand challenges like forecasting responses of ecological systems to genetic changes. KSU expects to help protect the nation through developing better understanding of threats to key agricultural products, like the Hessian fly, which attacks wheat. KSU also plans to gain insight into advanced networking and its interaction with controlling the effects of brownouts or sabotage on the electrical grid; and significantly enhance and integrate educational efforts at all levels for data-driven computing, particularly in bioinformatics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proposal requested NSF support for enhancing the internal networking capabilities at Kansas State University to support high-end applications in science and engineering, particularly bioinformatics, with applications in SDN/OpenFlow research related to the NSF-funded GENI effort, and privacy/ security. This proposal leveraged two recent grants: “Prairie Light” (NSF EPS-1006860), which upgraded the Kansas backbone network to 10 Gb/s, and an MRI (NSF CNS-1006860) which more than doubled the computational power of our local Beowulf cluster, “Beocat,” by eliminating the 1 Gb/s on-campus bottleneck which was preventing our researchers from fully effectively collaborating with both local and distance partners. This also provides a testbed for research and educational outreach to K-12, community college, and Kansas-wide academics to explore bioinformatics, security, advanced networking via OpenFlow, and HPC.

We purchased a pair of high-performance, low-latency set of OpenFlow-compatible enterprise routers with a 40GbE core and plentiful 10GbE ports to provide a foundation for upgrading our campus core network to 40GbE, and 10GbE to most major research buildings on campus, including end-to-end connectivity for our campus supercomputer cluster, the Arthropod Genomics Center, the Integrated Genomics Facility, and the campus GIS center (GISSAL). We also had another router donated by Cisco to set up a science DMZ for research in OpenFlow/GENI/SDN and Smart Grid research, with end-to-end connectivity with the KSU GENI and Smart Grid labs. This impacts over 24 departments in 16 locations, 8,000 undergrad majors, 2,000 grad students, 700 faculty, and $88M in funded research.

The impact of the improved network connectivity has been substantial. Dr. I. Ciampitti (Agronomy), who researches sorghum production, notes "Increasing our connectivity helped our team to be more active on the front of developing new tools (Apps) and also in using the cloud for storing information, sharing data with the team here in the building but also outside of the state and the country (with colleagues in Brazil, Argentina, and Australia)." Dr. J. Chen says “the increased connectivity and storage have opened up a lot of potential research work” in financial markets using SEC data. Dr. S. Brown (Biology), studying insect pests, celebrates “We love doing data analysis in real time… We are now getting whole genome maps for 2.5 Gb mammalian genomes in 2 days instead of 2 weeks."
